awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Corpus of New York City English: Audio-Aligned and Parsed
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to further the study of New York City English (NYCE) - the varieties of English particular to New York City and the surrounding region - through the development and use of an innovative audio-aligned and parsed corpus of New Yorkers' speech. The project will combine recent advances in speech corpus development tools with the special talents and backgrounds of undergraduates at the City University of New York (CUNY), to create the first such corpus of New York City English (the CUNY-CoNYCE). The CUNY-CoNYCE will be based on interviews with New Yorkers across the five boroughs and Long Island, conducted by CUNY undergraduates from Queens College, Lehman College (The Bronx), and the College of Staten Island. Because our student populations draw predominantly from neighborhoods across the five boroughs of New York City and Long Island, they are uniquely able to collectively gather and produce large quantities of speech data from all over the region. The ultimate product will be an on-line, freely accessible, ~1,000,000-word audio-aligned and grammatically annotated corpus of NYCE speech, which will be accompanied by a full set of digital, text-searchable recordings of the speech signal from which the corpus is transcribed.

In addition to answering questions about language variation and change in NYCE, the corpus will further research in all areas of linguistics, especially in phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, sociolinguistics, and discourse analysis. The use of oral history and sociological measurements of ethnic affiliation components in data collection will also make the CUNY-CoNYCE a useful tool for sociologists and anthropologists examining lived experience in urban settings, inter-ethnic relations, and near-term history of New York life. The project will also provide transformative research experiences for dozens of CUNY undergraduates, giving them unique research opportunities. Additionally, users of the corpus will develop an understanding of and appreciation for the grammar of non-standard dialects, and functions of non-standard speech as necessary linguistic resources for social integration.

por.por_cntn:
The outcome of this project is the creation of a one-million+ word corpus of New York City English (NYCE). The corpus, which is called the "CUNY Corpus of New York City English" (or, "CUNY-CoNYCE" for short), serves as a resource unprecedented in scope and in public accessibility for cultural and linguistic research on the English of New York City. It is based on interviews with New Yorkers across the five boroughs and Long Island, conducted by hundreds of City University of New York (CUNY) undergraduates from Queens College, Lehman College (The Bronx), and the College of Staten Island. Because our CUNY student researchers are themselves New Yorkers, they were uniquely able to collectively gather and produce large quantities of speech data from all over the region. Their recorded interviews have been transcribed in Praat (a free software package for speech analysis) in "textgrid" format. A textgrid is a type of transcription which is time-aligned with the audio of the recorded interviews. The audio and the time-aligned transcriptions are made available to the public through kratylos.org<https://urldefense.com/v3/__http://kratylos.org__;!!GekbXoL5ynDpFgM!UJ3okEDJlrGbQZ20yNlZFxajau23KTLiPSITMpbGx4Y9asAzXxXQvjqguwmCUU1fTiFZV3zGdyePYqsCl3R6jkqloA$>. Once grammatically annotated, they will also be available as a parsed corpus using the same format as the Audio-Aligned and Parsed Corpus of Appalachian English (AAPCAppE) (see www.aapcappe.org<https://urldefense.com/v3/__http://www.aapcappe.org__;!!GekbXoL5ynDpFgM!UJ3okEDJlrGbQZ20yNlZFxajau23KTLiPSITMpbGx4Y9asAzXxXQvjqguwmCUU1fTiFZV3zGdyePYqsCl3TIBu751g$> for the model). Because the corpus is searchable online with both garden-variety text-searching techniques and with standard computational tools, it fosters replicability, thereby contributing to increased empirical rigor in linguistic research. A 2022 article by B. Haddican et al. in the journal American Speech ("Cross-speaker covariation across six vocalic changes in New York City English," winner of the Roger Shuy Award for best article published in the journal for 2022) serves as proof of concept for the ways in which CUNY-CoNYCE can be used to study variation and change in a regional variety of English. The use of sociological measurements of ethnic affiliation in data collection also make the CUNY-CoNYCE a useful tool for sociologists and anthropologists examining lived experience in urban settings, inter-ethnic relations, and near-term history of New York life. Additionally, users of the corpus can develop an understanding of and appreciation for the grammar of non-standardized varieties, and for the functions of non-standardized speech as necessary linguistic resources for social integration.
